content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice Idea! Perfect difficulty
I love the idea! Nice work!

Note in some languages, like python, all this is part of the builtin methods.

n = int(input())
format = f'{{:0{length}}}'
print(format.format(n))

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I accept this contribution because it's good. It took me roughly 8 minutes to solve as reverse, therefore I pretty liked it.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Previous suggestions were indeed necessary, but once applied the clash was fast to understand and not too trivial to solve.
I like it !

Very confusing statement, but the example makes things obvious. I would reword it as:

"Given a list of integers, pad each integer on the left with zeroes so that all integers have the same length. Use the shortest length possible."

I think using [[f]] is unnecessary and actually a little confusing. I would remove it and only mention 0 ≤ length of integer ≤ 200 in the constraints. For that matter, it should be 0 < length, not 0 ≤ length. You also need a constraint on [[n]].

You need to add a constraint on the length of numbers

Also i find this condition :
"if all the numbers have one zero in front of them you can remove that zero from all of them. If removing extra zeroes gives you an empty string do not output that line" 
unnecessarily complicated and confusing. Why would you not print the zeros all the way instead of not printing. It just makes it inconsistent. and the way it's written makes it even more confusing. I'd suggest you get rid of this special case and just print all zeros with the required width.
Yes you are right about that, i messed that up when writing it. I edited it a bit, made it a bit clearer without changing the entire goal. i hope it is better now, this is my first contribution.
I like your advice, I updated it a bit like you recommended.

The "Do not output a line if it is all zeroes." is clear but will not be available in reverse mode.

I would prefer to output zeros all the way as ANONYMOUS42 suggested.

Also the only test case where we have the issue is in "Many numbers", I would have a sperate test case for the zeros case if kept.
I added another test case at the end with lines of only zeroes, though I do think it is not too complicated.
Ok, not complicated but I don't get why it is a special case;
